paragraphs.text: Defusing Taliban publicity.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Journalists in Afghanistan have decided for the second time this year to curtail their reporting on Taliban attacks as a means of reducing the impact of their message
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The first such collective action was taken during the presidential elections
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when the Taliban were completely boycotted
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is a strategic decision according to Fahim Dashty, the chief executive of Afghanistan's National Journalists Union (ANJU)
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The decision follows the recent heavy escalation of attacks in Kabul
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Our media is saturated with images of Taliban attacks," says a joint press statement by ANJU, and the media watchdog, Nai
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Taliban spokesman Zabihula Mujahid is active on TV and social media round the clock, he is in every home 24 hours a day, we need to confront his messages," says Nai's director, Sediqulah Tauhidi
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Afghan journalists feel they need support from policy makers and the international community alike
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "We will be calling on the new president, Ashraf Ghani, to consider blocking the sites that Taliban use for their publicity," says Dashty
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Confronting publicity
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The call by journalists in Afghanistan echoes international concerns about the need to confront publicity by armed groups such as ISIL, and the attempts in several countries including Britain to block these groups' use of the internet and social media to advertise, publicise and recruit
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: British Home Secretary Theresa May acknowledged the extent of the problem in her latest policy speech:"We need a counter terrorism strategy that is comprehensive and coherent."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Among the measures to curb the activities of the Islamist terror groups she introduced restrictions on the use of the internet
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "We are engaged in a struggle that is fought on many fronts," she said, naming terrorist groups in several parts of the world including Afghanistan
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Police and intelligence agencies will be given new powers to track down those who plot terrorist attacks over the internet
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "They enable the authorities to limit a subject's access to telephones and the internet," she said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Terrorist attacks have been complex
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: many are used for sending a specific message either to the local population or to the international community
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Once these messages are turned into images on TV and internet across the world their impact is amplified
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Broader audience
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: According to UN counterterrorism research, terrorist-related propaganda hosted on popular websites containing user-generated content has the potential to reach a significantly broader audience than content on traditional specialised websites, bulletin boards and web forums
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which generally appeal to a self- selected group of individuals
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Their sophisticated use of the internet and social media means they have a significant propaganda reach across the world," said the British home secretary
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "The scourge of ISIL should not mean that the Taliban are forgotten or seen as the milder terror group," stresses Dashty
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: There are serious reservations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond states at the opening of the London Conference on Afghanistan that "The terrorist threat from the region has been substantially reduced,"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: when there are almost daily attacks in Kabul
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "Taliban are blocking the fledgling democracy that has been built over the last decade," says Nai director
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "They are attacking our liberty, they are targeting freedom of speech, they are targeting press freedom and we must have a counter offensive."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Dashty says as journalists we must ask ourselves whether in our endeavour to provide information we are turning into communication channels at the service of the Taliban
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The arguments are not straightforward
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the one hand
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the media needs to report to inform the population
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: on the other hand
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: reporting terrorist attacks has increasingly become publicity for armed extremist groups
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the one hand freedom of speech and civil liberties should be preserved at all cost
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: on the other hand
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: terrorist messages have traumatised societies and increased militant recruitment around the world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Credible counter-narrative
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: These issues must be discussed in depth and collectively around the world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There is a need for coordinating a credible counter narrative both at the local and the global level to confront the banality and cruelty of terrorist messages
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Take for example their claim, believed even by some analysts, that they are fighting to save Muslims
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: facts tell us that they have killed tens of thousands over the years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Since 2009, there have been over 17,000 civilian deaths in Afghanistan alone as documented by the UN - 75 percent as a result of Taliban attacks
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Or the contradictions in the Taliban claim that they want foreign forces out while targeting British interests one month after British forces left Afghanistan, or inviting foreign Islamist fighters and al-Qaeda to set up camp in Afghanistan during their rule
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Confusion and contradictions among the various terrorist voices" are common according to the latest State Department report on terrorism
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Journalists, media analysts, communication experts and policy makers need to come together to discuss how best to build a framework for a new counterterrorism narrative that at the same time reveals the falsities of terrorist assertions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Once formulated, it could then be used as any public service broadcast messages woven into drama serials, discussions, debates and news coverage alike
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The UN Office on Drugs and Crime, which created a counterterrorism task force, says that despite increasing international recognition of the threat posed by terrorists' use of the internet,"there is currently no universal instrument specifically addressing this pervasive facet of terrorist activity"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: 'Psychological security'
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The joint statement by ANJU and Nai calls on the media and the reporters in Afghanistan to refrain from competition over who shows more pictures of the gruesome Taliban attacks
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It says that the "unprecedented" frequency of the footage shown on TV and social media have undermined the "psychological security" of the nation
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Our first boycott of the Taliban was successful," says Dashty
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Attacks were reduced and over 60 percent of the population took part in the elections."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He says they would really benefit if journalists in the West supported their campaigns, especially those who frequently report from Afghanistan
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "We would also welcome an international framework that sets an example for us," says Dashty
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: A coordinated global plan to counter terrorist media propaganda would be a useful tool for journalists in areas adversely affected by terrorist attacks
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Attacks plotted on the World Wide Web need an appropriate worldwide media response
paragraphs.label: assumption
